text_final: Invite skeptics to a structured Q&A
subtitle: Invite skeptics to ask questions in a structured session.
rationale: Brings rumours and worries into the open; Shows respect for critical voices; Allows managers to correct misunderstandings with everyone listening.
citation_text: Balogun, J., & Johnson, G. (2005). From intended strategies to unintended outcomes: The impact of change-recipient sensemaking. Organization Studies, 26(11), 1573–1601.
evidence_summary: Qualitative study showing how engaging sceptics can reduce unintended outcomes.

text_final: Visualize dependencies on other teams in one chart
subtitle: Show in one picture which teams depend on whom.
rationale: Makes lateral dependencies visible; Reduces surprises at interfaces between teams; Helps plan coordination and sequencing of work.
citation_text: Balogun, J., & Johnson, G. (2005). From intended strategies to unintended outcomes: The impact of change-recipient sensemaking. Organization Studies, 26(11), 1573–1601.
evidence_summary: Qualitative study of how sideways sensemaking at interfaces shapes change outcomes.

text_final: Set an escalation SLA for unresolved blockers
subtitle: Agree on how quickly unresolved blockers will be escalated.
rationale: Gives teams a clear path when they get stuck; Prevents issues from lingering in silence; Helps managers prioritise support across many DT initiatives.
citation_text: Henderikx, M., & Stoffers, J. (2023). Digital transformation and middle managers’ leadership skills & behavior: a group concept mapping approach. Frontiers in Psychology, 14, 1147002.
evidence_summary: Group concept mapping study highlighting fast unblocking as an important behaviour.

text_final: Protect 2 hours/week for learning tied to the goal
subtitle: Set aside protected time each week for learning tied to the DT goals.
rationale: Signals that learning is part of the job, not an extra; Gives people space to build new skills without burnout; Increases the chances that new tools are actually adopted.
citation_text: Henderikx, M., & Stoffers, J. (2023). Digital transformation and middle managers’ leadership skills & behavior: a group concept mapping approach. Frontiers in Psychology, 14, 1147002.
evidence_summary: Group concept mapping study identifying learning support as a key middle-manager behaviour in DT.

text_final: Post a visual of handoffs removed
subtitle: Show which handoffs or steps disappear with the new way of working.
rationale: Makes the efficiency gains of DT visible; Helps teams see how their workload and interactions will change; Reinforces the message that the change is simplifying work, not just adding tasks.
citation_text: Rouleau, L. (2005). Micro-practices of strategic sensemaking and sensegiving. Journal of Management Studies, 42(7), 1413–1441.
evidence_summary: Ethnographic study on visualising enacted changes in workflows.

text_final: Demo working software instead of slides
subtitle: Show the real tool in use instead of talking about it in slides.
rationale: Builds trust that the change is real, not just talk; Reveals practical questions that only appear when people see the tool; Helps users imagine themselves using the new system.
citation_text: Rouleau, L. (2005). Micro-practices of strategic sensemaking and sensegiving. Journal of Management Studies, 42(7), 1413–1441.
evidence_summary: Ethnographic study showing how demonstrations make abstract strategy tangible.

text_final: Share three user stories that embody the goal
subtitle: Share three short stories that illustrate the DT goal in action.
rationale: Makes abstract goals vivid and memorable; Shows what “good” looks like in real situations; Encourages teams to imagine how similar stories could happen in their area.
citation_text: Rouleau, L. (2005). Micro-practices of strategic sensemaking and sensegiving. Journal of Management Studies, 42(7), 1413–1441.
evidence_summary: Ethnographic study of how stories and examples make strategy understandable.

subtitle: Draw how work looks today versus after the DT change.
rationale: Helps people see concretely what will be different; Surfaces hidden steps and pain points; Makes it easier to spot where support or training is needed.
citation_text: Rouleau, L. (2005). Micro-practices of strategic sensemaking and sensegiving. Journal of Management Studies, 42(7), 1413–1441.
evidence_summary: Ethnographic study of how managers use concrete artefacts in everyday sensegiving.

text_final: Use a single channel for official goal updates
subtitle: Use one official channel so people know where to look for updates.
rationale: Reduces drift between different versions of the story; Makes it easier for people to catch up if they miss a meeting; Lowers noise from competing messages.
citation_text: Maitlis, S. (2005). The social processes of organizational sensemaking. Academy of Management Journal, 48(1), 21–49.
evidence_summary: Sensemaking research on how communication patterns shape collective understanding.

text_final: Pin the latest goal post at the top
subtitle: Make the latest official goal message easy to find.
rationale: Reduces confusion about which version of the goal is current; Helps align conversations across teams; Makes it easier to onboard new people into the DT story.
citation_text: Maitlis, S., & Christianson, M. (2014). Sensemaking in organizations: Taking stock and moving forward. The Academy of Management Annals, 8(1), 57–125.
evidence_summary: Review of sensemaking research emphasising the role of salient cues and signals.

text_final: Map goals to owners (who does what by when)
subtitle: Clarify who is responsible for what and by when.
rationale: Reduces ambiguity about next steps; Makes follow-through visible; Helps coordinate work across teams.
citation_text: Floyd, S. W., & Wooldridge, B. (1997). Middle management’s strategic influence and organizational performance. Journal of Management Studies, 34(3), 465–485.
evidence_summary: Strategy research showing that clear ownership improves execution quality.

text_final: Translate DT goals into 2–3 team KPIs
subtitle: Boil each digital-transformation goal down to a few team-level KPIs.
rationale: Connects abstract strategy to everyday numbers; Makes it easier for teams to see if they are contributing; Strengthens accountability for DT progress.
citation_text: Floyd, S. W., & Wooldridge, B. (1997). Middle management’s strategic influence and organizational performance. Journal of Management Studies, 34(3), 465–485.
evidence_summary: Strategy research on how middle managers use metrics to link goals and performance.

text_final: Acknowledge one loss/concern with next steps
subtitle: Name a concern and explain what will happen next.
rationale: Validates people’s losses instead of ignoring them; Prevents resistance from building underground; Links difficult news to a constructive path forward.
citation_text: Huy, Q. N. (2002). Emotional balancing of organizational continuity and radical change: The contribution of middle managers. Administrative Science Quarterly, 47(1), 31–69.
evidence_summary: Qualitative study showing how acknowledging loss helps maintain trust in change.

text_final: Celebrate a tiny win every Friday
subtitle: Mark small wins regularly to show progress and build confidence.
rationale: Keeps morale up during long, uncertain change; Makes progress visible even when big milestones are far away; Encourages teams to notice what is working.
citation_text: Huy, Q. N. (2002). Emotional balancing of organizational continuity and radical change: The contribution of middle managers. Administrative Science Quarterly, 47(1), 31–69.
evidence_summary: Qualitative study of how middle managers use emotions to sustain radical change.

text_final: Provide role-based “what changes for me” cards
subtitle: Give each role a short card explaining what will change for them.
rationale: Tailors the DT story to what each person cares about; Reduces confusion about how generic goals apply locally; Supports local planning and delegation.
citation_text: Rouleau, L. (2005). Micro-practices of strategic sensemaking and sensegiving. Journal of Management Studies, 42(7), 1413–1441.
evidence_summary: Ethnographic study showing how tailored translations help people act on strategy.

text_final: Specify what data will prove the goal is met
subtitle: Turn the DT goal into 1–2 concrete numbers everyone can track.
rationale: Aligns everyone on the same proof of success; Reduces debates about whether the goal is achieved; Helps teams prioritise among competing requests.
citation_text: Maitlis, S. (2005). The social processes of organizational sensemaking. Academy of Management Journal, 48(1), 21–49.
evidence_summary: Sensemaking study showing how shared cues and measures guide collective action.

subtitle: Summarise the DT journey into a small set of waypoints.
rationale: Gives people a shared picture of where the change is going; Prevents overload from too many milestones; Helps teams time their own contributions.
citation_text: Gioia, D. A., & Chittipeddi, K. (1991). Sensemaking and sensegiving in strategic change initiation. Strategic Management Journal, 12(6), 433–448.
evidence_summary: Qualitative study of how leaders frame and pace early strategic change.

text_final: Highlight top 3 risks and how we’re containing them
subtitle: Make key risks and your mitigation plan transparent.
rationale: Reduces anxiety by naming what could go wrong; Builds trust by showing how risks are being managed; Helps teams prepare instead of speculate.
citation_text: Weick, K. E. (1995). Sensemaking in Organizations. Sage.
evidence_summary: Sensemaking work on how surfacing and containing risks supports coordination.

text_final: Keep a living FAQ of recurring goal questions
subtitle: Capture recurring questions and keep answers up to date.
rationale: Prevents leaders from answering the same questions repeatedly; Shows that concerns are heard and addressed; Provides a stable reference when rumours circulate.
citation_text: Weick, K. E. (1995). Sensemaking in Organizations. Sage.
evidence_summary: Conceptual work on how ongoing artefacts help stabilise shared meaning.
